title: Hard Problems Are Still Hard: How AI Agents Change the Tools—but Not the Work

paragraphs.content: In late 2025, a growing chorus across robotics, AI, and design is rallying around a blunt refrain: **“hard problems are still hard.”**Robotics commentators note that despite rapid advances in autonomy and agentic AI, basic real‑world challenges—like robust perception, long‑horizon planning, and safe navigation in unstructured environments—continue to block large‑scale deployment.Industry surveys and forecasts show that high implementation cost and reliability concerns remain the top barriers to rolling out autonomous systems, even as compute and model capabilities accelerate.This context has turned the phrase into a kind of reality check on AI hype, framing new tools as powerful but fundamentally constrained.

paragraphs.content: The same theme is surfacing far beyond robotics labs, from Figma’s product and design community to enterprise AI strategists and software engineers.Designers like Figma’s Nikolas Klein argue that while AI-native tools and real‑time collaboration platforms reshape workflows, the core work of defining strategy, aligning stakeholders, and making judgment calls has not become easier.Investors and founders, meanwhile, are explicitly looking for “hard problems” to back in 2025—from industrial robotics to lab automation—on the premise that tooling gains have not yet dissolved structural bottlenecks.Together, these perspectives position agentic AI as an accelerant for human expertise, not a substitute for the deeply contextual, constraint‑laden work that remains stubbornly hard.

sections.title: From Agentic AI to Humanoids: Robotics Meets the Limits of the Real World

paragraphs.content: Robotics roadmaps for 2025 and beyond openly acknowledge that core constraints—cost, safety, and performance in messy environments—are proving resistant to quick AI fixes.Even as autonomy improves, many robots still struggle outdoors, on rough terrain, or in unpredictable settings, and surveys of robotics developers identify high implementation cost as the single biggest barrier to wider adoption.Detailed polling of product developers and industrial designers finds that 73.4% cite cost as the top obstacle, while roughly half highlight safety and reliability in dynamic, human‑filled spaces as a central unsolved challenge.These numbers echo expert interviews and public talks in which roboticists emphasize that tasks that feel trivial to humans—like folding laundry or reliably grasping varied household objects—remain disproportionately difficult for machines.

paragraphs.content: Analysts tracking robotics trends say this tension is shaping where robots will actually appear over the next decade: factories and warehouses long before living rooms. Their surveys show deep skepticism about near‑term humanoid robots in elder care or domestic chores, with only small minorities of experts expecting such systems to be ready soon, despite intense investment. At the same time, investors are looking for “industrial robotic leapfrogging” and lab automation plays, betting that focused, structured environments can yield real gains even as general‑purpose autonomy lags.Across these domains, the message is consistent: new AI agents, digital twins, and better simulation pipelines help, but they run into the same old walls of physics, safety standards, and economic viability that have defined robotics for years.

sections.title: Design, Software, and Security: When Better Tools Don’t Erase the Hard Parts

paragraphs.content: In digital product work, Figma’s own blog has turned “hard problems are still hard” into a narrative about AI-augmented design rather than AI‑replaced designers.Nikolas Klein’s Maker Story recounts a complex rebrand where modern tools—cloud collaboration, shared design systems, and emerging AI features—smoothed execution but did not simplify the underlying challenges of brand definition, cross‑functional alignment, and timing a funding round.Adjacent Figma posts on AI image editing, design systems in the AI era, and the blurring boundaries between designers, developers, and product managers all stress that while AI can speed up production work, it doesn’t resolve ambiguity or make trade‑offs for teams.That same framing appears in broader technical writing and podcasts, where engineers and security experts use the phrase to describe multi‑threading pitfalls, long‑term maintenance burdens, and open‑source supply‑chain risks that persist despite more sophisticated languages and tooling.

paragraphs.content: Enterprise AI strategists have begun codifying this into a design principle: agentic AI should be treated as a powerful system component, not a magic product that dissolves organizational and computational constraints. Commentaries on “agentic AI in the enterprise” argue that most failed pilots stem not from weak models but from underestimating integration complexity, governance, and the need for human judgment in high‑stakes decisions. Educational material on large language models similarly warns that computational limits and S‑curves of diminishing returns mean many NP‑hard and real‑world planning problems will not be “solved” by scale alone, even if subsets become more tractable. Security podcasts and industry blogs extend the lesson further, showing how vulnerabilities in mature ecosystems like Kubernetes and the wider open‑source stack keep surfacing, underscoring that better tools can shift where the work happens—but not the fact that someone still has to wrestle with the hard parts.
